problem: Laptop turns on but no display
solution: Ensure brightness is not turned all the way down. Disconnect any external display and try restarting. If still black, the RAM may need reseating.
Check the charging port for dust. Try a different power outlet or charger. If the light shows charging but percentage doesn’t increase, recalibrate or replace the battery.
Clean air vents and ensure fans are spinning. Avoid using on soft surfaces and consider applying new thermal paste if it overheats frequently.
The fan may have dust buildup or be misaligned. Use compressed air to clean it. Replace the fan if the noise persists.
Turn airplane mode off, restart the router, and forget and reconnect to the network. Update WiFi drivers if the issue persists.
Ensure Bluetooth is enabled in Settings. Restart the Bluetooth service, and reinstall the Bluetooth driver from Device Manager.
Check background processes in Task Manager. Uninstall unused apps, run disk cleanup, and consider upgrading RAM or switching to an SSD.
Check for overheating or full storage. Run antivirus scan, update drivers, and disable startup apps that aren’t needed.
Check for dirt or liquid under the keys. Reinstall keyboard drivers or try an external keyboard to confirm hardware issues.
Make sure touchpad is enabled using Fn key (often Fn + F6/F7). Reinstall touchpad drivers and check for software conflicts.
Restart your computer, update chipset drivers, and check the power settings for USB selective suspend options.
Reduce brightness, close background apps, disable Bluetooth/WiFi when not needed, and replace the battery if it’s old.
Usually due to overheating or power failure. Clean the fans, check thermal paste, and test with another adapter.
Check if sound is muted or set to the wrong output device. Reinstall or update your audio driver.
Check app permissions in sound settings. Update audio input driver and test with another app or external mic.
Check the HDMI or VGA connection. Use Windows + P to switch display mode and update your graphics driver.
Lower screen refresh rate in settings or update graphics drivers. Check for loose display cables.
Enter BIOS to see if it appears there. Check SATA connection or test the drive on another system.
Ensure NVMe/SATA mode is properly set in BIOS. Try reseating the SSD or updating firmware.
Run startup repair using Windows installation media. Check if boot order is correct in BIOS.
Disable automatic restart on system failure. Run antivirus and check for driver or Windows update issues.
Note the error code, then update all drivers. Check for overheating, faulty RAM, or corrupted system files.
Reset BIOS to default settings. Disconnect all external devices and restart.
The beep code indicates a hardware issue. Count the beeps and refer to your laptop manual for diagnosis (often RAM or GPU).
You may need to reset BIOS by removing the CMOS battery or contacting the manufacturer for a master key.
Clean the vents, use a cooling pad, and ensure your GPU drivers are updated. Avoid high-performance mode on battery.
Some updates rebuild indexes or drivers. Let it run for a while or uninstall recent updates from settings.
You’ll need to replace the screen panel. Contact service center or use an external monitor temporarily.
Use Ctrl + Alt + Up Arrow to fix orientation or change rotation in display settings.
Wait at least 30 minutes, then hold power button to force restart. Boot into Safe Mode if needed.
Update or reinstall the problematic software. Check for OS updates and clear temporary cache files.
Check power plan settings. Disable background apps preventing sleep, and update chipset drivers.
Unplug the charger, drain battery completely, and recharge fully. Calibrate if issue persists.
Try another USB port or system. Assign a drive letter from Disk Management if it’s not appearing.
Ensure WiFi or USB connection is stable. Reinstall printer drivers and restart both devices.
Clean the sensor area. Update mouse drivers or reduce pointer speed in settings.
Replace the CMOS battery on the motherboard. Sync clock with internet time server.
Ensure RAM is compatible and properly seated. Update BIOS and check max supported capacity.
Run activation troubleshooter or re-enter your product key. Contact Microsoft support if needed.
